Received: September 29, 2011; Revised: June 8, 2012; Accepted: July 4, 2012

The cybercrime ecosystem: Online innovation in the shadows?

AFFILIATION:
a CENTRIM - Centre for Research in Innovation Management, University of Brighton, Freeman Centre, Brighton BN1 9QE, UK


b SPRU - Science and Technology Policy Research, University of Sussex, Freeman Centre, Brighton BN1 9QE, UK

Erika Kraemer-Mbula aPuay Tang bHoward Rush a, *, H.J.Rush@Brighton.ac.uk

With the growing sophistication and use of information technology, the past decade has witnessed a major growth in financial cybercrime. This paper focuses specifically on credit card fraud and identity theft, examining the globalisation of these activities within a 'digital ecosystem' conceptual framework. The relevance of concepts and analytical tools typically used to study legitimate businesses, such as value chains, dynamic capabilities and business models, is explored and tested for their relevance in understanding the scale and nature of illegal activities which are dependant upon innovation and the collective activities of global participants. It is argued that developing a better understanding of how such illegal activities are organised and operate will assist policy makers, law enforcement agencies and security firms to identify trends and concentrate limited resources in a most effective manner.

–º Innovations within cybercrime represent the cutting edge of global criminal activity. –º Economic recession plus ICT skill surplus creates opportunities for cybercrime. –º Cybercriminals are increasingly operating in a business ecosystem.

1 Introduction

Innovation is at the heart of the growth of illegal Internet-based activities commonly known as cybercrime [40,50,60]. Criminal organisations are not only incorporating emerging technologies in their activities, but are increasingly pioneering and seizing opportunities for new illegal enterprises made possible by the Internet and the continuing growth of electronic commerce.

Arguably, many of these innovations represent the cutting edge of global criminal activity. They provide higher prospects for illicit profits at seemingly lower degrees of risk. Security analysts can have difficulty in identifying the locations from where the cybercriminals may be operating (see Table1 below) and find it difficult to identify the perpetrators. Cybercrime thus represents the growing sophistication of existing criminal behaviour and the emergence of novel illegal cyber activities. It presents unique and difficult challenges for law enforcement officers charged with countering such activities.

Despite being an innovation-driven phenomenon, most analysis of cybercrime has been undertaken from the perspectives of criminology, information and communications technology (ICT) security firms and journalists, rather than innovation scholars. The aim of this paper is to examine the evolution of cybercrime through the lens of innovation studies in order to develop a framework which aims to contribute to a new perspective on how cybercriminals innovate, organise and operate, and how law enforcement agencies must change to combat this growing trend.

The lack of systematic innovation-based analysis of cybercrime has left gaps in the understanding of how cybercrime has evolved into a large global 'business' within and connected to the Internet. To contribute to filling these gaps, this paper analyses the evolution of cybercrime through the borrowed concept of a "digital business ecosystem" [16, p. 3].

The conceptual framework in this article was developed and validated in a pilot study funded by the National Endowment for Science, Technology and the Arts (NESTA). This article draws upon and updates Rush, H; Smith, C; Tang, P. and Kraemer-Mbula, E. "Crime online: Cybercrime and illegal innovation", NESTA, 2009. As argued below, this particular framework promises valuable and comprehensive innovation insights because it combines elements of innovation study, value chain analysis, capability theory and business model examination.

 We suggest that by deepening our understanding of the cybercrime ecosystem it may be possible for the relevant authorities to more rapidly identify trends and forecast new developments. In so doing they should be able to more effectively concentrate their limited resources in dealing with cybercrime.

James Moore [39], in his McKinsey award-winning article, introduced this concept which has become widely used by social scientists and students of business and organisational management and design. Moore defined a business ecosystem as: "a loose network of suppliers, distributors and outsourced firms that work cooperatively and competitively to support new products, satisfy consumer needs and incorporate innovation".

Quoted in [16].

According to his view, firms do not belong to a single industry, but their activities cut across multiple industries. Refining his concept further [40: 26], he added that an ecosystem is: "an economic community supported by a foundation of interacting organisations and individuals-the organisms of the business world. The economic community produces goods and services of value to customers, who are themselves members of the ecosystem. The member organisms also include suppliers, lead producers, competitors, and other stakeholders".

Other scholars have further elaborated on this concept by emphasising that entities of a business ecosystem have different interests but are interconnected through cooperation and competition, for their mutual survival and effectiveness [62]. Analogous to natural ecosystems, business ecosystems are characterised by "interconnectedness" and "shared fate" among diverse organisations, "that contributes to their collective productivity and robustness" [45: 104].

It is worth noting that these authors, particularly Iansiti and Levien [62], with whom the term ecosystem is also much associated in the strategy literature, adopt the ecosystem concept to provide a perspective on business strategy and business networks.

Drawing on this concept, we argue that there is merit to analysing the cybercrime network in terms of a digital business ecosystem, which depends on information and communication technologies, responds to its environment, is interdependent on various entities and continually innovates in order to be effective and survive. We label this ecosystem as the "cybercrime ecosystem".

Furthermore, the business ecosystem provides a perspective that can be used to analyse interconnected businesses, that is "by looking at the relationships or interactions among the members and their environment and at the roles and interests of the members of the system" [8,11,18].

We acknowledge that there is a plethora of literature on business networks, which among other things, study the 'connectedness' of business networks and the diffusion of innovation. However we differ from these studies by focusing on the ecosystem's evolving and dynamic characteristic through 'internal innovation'.

As will be discussed, financial cybercrime is an "interconnected" business, with different roles and interests of the constituents of this network. In addition to a variety of criminal participants, the cybercrime ecosystem includes legitimate businesses, such as IT security firms, banking and financial services. For instance, IT security firms interact with organisations in the financial services when they have to develop new measures to identify new attacks and to deal with the vulnerabilities found in network infrastructures. Cybercriminals, in turn, have to further hone their skills and develop ever more sophisticated malicious tools to infect the digital networks and to circumvent security measures. In a sense, these two communities, perversely, have a shared fate, as if participating in a game of innovation leapfrogging as one set of actors in the ecosystem attempts to counter the advances and responses of another set of actors.

Drawing from existing literature and the results from an exploratory study involving academics, IT security firms, law enforcement officers, financial institutions and policymakers [46], this paper first defines the types of cybercrime before examining the conceptual foundations of the cybercrime ecosystem and its three core elements. They are (1) the international value chains (networks) which link activities and actors; (2) the changing capabilities that underlie the ecosystem; and (3) the business models that arise from the changing capabilities and concomitant innovations and strategies.

2 What is cybercrime?

Cybercrime covers a wide range of activities relating to the use of information technology for criminal purposes. The modernisation of 'traditional' crimes such as drug trafficking, terrorism, money laundering and extortion through the frequent incorporation of computer and mobile technologies is well known [63,23,58].

Although illegality is inherent in the concept, cybercrime is not a legal term and its definition and coverage continuously evolve with advances in communication technologies (from computer crime to electronic and virtual crime). Cybercrime, in essence describes all kinds of crime using telecommunications networks, in which computers or computer networks are a tool, a target, or a locale of criminal activity [2]. According to Wall [58: 221]: "Cybercrimes are criminal or harmful activities that are informational, global and networked and are to be distinguished from crimes that simply use computers. They are the product of networked technologies that have transformed the division of criminal labour to provide entirely new opportunities and new forms of crime which typically involve the acquisition or manipulation of information and its value across global networks for gain. They can be broken down into crimes that are related to the integrity of the system, crimes in which networked computers are used to assist the perpetration of crime, and crimes which relate to the content of computers."

By this definition cybercrime takes many forms, depending on its final purpose and means, and classifications are as varied as the number of studies on the subject.

Numerous definitions for cybercrime can be found in the literature. We have adopted the one provided by David [58] in his book on the subject because of its useful recognition of the informational, global and networked characteristics, which helps to locate the type of crimes with the technologies that facilitate them. Wall's definition is highly compatible with the innovation studies approach which we have adopted for this study.

This paper focuses on financial cybercrime. Other types of cybercrime such as offences against the person (cyberstalking, harassment, blackmailing, bullying), computer misuse (denial of service

There have been several well-published attacks on gaming websites, which effectively closed down the sites until a ransom has been paid.

 and software piracy), distribution of illicit material (child pornography and promotion of activities amongst paedophiles), Intellectual Property theft and industrial espionage are beyond the scope of this paper. Within financial cybercrimes, this study looks specifically at credit card fraud and identity theft.

We use the term 'credit card fraud' to encompass all forms of fraud involving credit, debit and charge cards.

 These two often-interrelated cybercrimes share with legitimate businesses the ultimate goal of financial profit.

Credit card fraud refers to the illicit use of stolen credit cards and credit card details (numbers and credit card 'dumps'

Dump is a slang word for stolen credit card information and usually contains, among other things, name and address of cardholder, account number, expiration date and verification/CVV2 code.

). This information can be obtained by several means such as card skimming - stealing the information off the magnetic stripe in automated teller machines (ATMs) or pin entry devices in commercial establishments; phishing schemes - acquiring the details by faking an email from a legitimate organisation (i.e. bank); or stealing information in personal computers or database systems using Trojans

A Trojan is a programme that appears benign, but actually contains a harmful load (e.g. an attachments on virus-bearing messages).

 or hacking.

Hacking commonly refers to obtaining unauthorised access to systems through skills, tactics and detailed knowledge.

According to a recent report [61], credit card information was the most advertised category on underground economy servers, ranking the highest in terms of supplied and demanded information in 2009. The reasons for their high popularity are: (a) the frequencies of credit card transactions as consumers have almost completely switched from traditional types of payment such as cash and cheques to debit and credit cards; and (b) growing preference for online transactions - the growth in e-commerce and online banking increases the opportunity for online theft of credit card information.

Identity theft is the misappropriation of somebody else's personal details, without their knowledge or consent. However, ID theft is not in itself an offence in the UK and penalties for those who make fraudulent applications (for example for passports) are very small [64]. Identity fraud occurs when the misappropriated and stolen identity is actually used in criminal activity, to obtain goods or services by deception, generally for financial gain.

ID theft generally combines online and offline methods. Online methods include stealing personal information stored in computer databases using Trojans or hacking; or through phishing,

Phishing refers to the process of attempting to acquire sensitive information such as usernames, passwords and credit card details, by masquerading as a trustworthy entity in an electronic communication. The practice is often done by sending e-mails that look as if they come from a financial institution and that seek to trick people into handing over confidential details.

vishing

Vishing refers to the criminal practice of using social engineering over the telephone, most often using features facilitated by Voice over IP (VoIP), to gain access to private personal and financial information for the purpose of financial reward. The term is a combination of 'voice' and phishing.

 and pharming.

Pharming is a fraudulent action aiming to redirect a website's traffic to another, bogus website. Pharming can be conducted either by changing the hosts file on a victim's computer or by exploitation of a vulnerability in DNS server software.

 Offline methods include intercepting bills and bank documents from the post and rubbish bins. These techniques allow cybercriminals to obtain Social Security or National Insurance

Or equivalence depending upon the country in which the theft takes place.

 numbers, bank or credit card account numbers, phone numbers, addresses, birth dates, usernames and passwords; all information that criminals can use to perform illicit transactions with another person's identity.

With even the most basic information, a criminal can either take over another person's existing financial accounts or use somebody's identity to create new ones. Common fraudster activities include withdrawing funds from one's accounts, charging purchases to one's credit cards, opening up new telephone accounts or taking out loans in ones name, all of which can have a damaging effect on the victim's credit rating.

 According to the UK Fraud Prevention Service (CIFAS), the top three false or stolen documents used by fraudsters attempting identity fraud in 2006 were: utility bills, passports and bank statements. In 2011 the UK Cabinet Office estimated that identity fraud had cost the UK economy £1.7billion in the previous year. CIFAS showed that fraud as a whole is on the rise, for instance, in 2005 the number of fraud cases identified was 152,176. By the end of 2010 this figure had risen to 217,385, of which 47% were ID frauds.

See .

3 Global trends in financial cybercrime

Financial cybercrime has increased dramatically in recent years worldwide. Advanced economies remain on top of the list as both originators and recipients of cybercriminal attacks.

According to Symantec [61] in 2008 computers from the United States were the leading source of Web-based attacks against users, accounting for 38% of the total worldwide. APWG [65] indicated that the US continued its position as the country hosting the most phishing sites during the fourth quarter of 2009.

However, from available data on cybercrime,

There are multiple sources of data for cybercrime, which illustrate: (i) trends on information security threats published regularly by security firms (e.g. Symantec, Sophos, MacAfee, Kaspersky, etc.); (ii) figures on victimization collected by organisations such as the Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3), or the UK National Fraud Reporting Centre (NFRC); (iii) financial losses from cybercriminals, reported by organisations, such as APACS (Association for Payment Clearing Services) in the UK.

 coupled with the proliferation and adoption of communications technology worldwide, together signal a potential for the continuing development of cybercriminal activities. The widespread availability of ICT skills, exacerbated by the downturn in the current global economy, provides potentially fertile ground for increased growth in financial cybercrimes.

The economics of security is also a significant contributing factor to the growth of financial cybercrime.

For a comprehensive discussion on this issue, see [7].

This is largely because companies rely on digital networks for their business operations, for instance, in e-banking and e-retailing. Indeed, a range of software-based mechanisms have been introduced and are regularly updated to prevent illegal behaviour in these transactions. For instance, the Digital Rights Management systems, which are aimed to prevent illegal downloading of movies and music; cryptographic methods for authentication of user and products; fraud-detection software, and an array of anti-virus software to secure computers and protect them against inherent vulnerabilities, are all common measures deployed to protect business operations and transactions.

Yet, as we will discuss, cybercriminals are in many cases, outflanking these mechanisms. Notably, the 'quality' of their countermeasures (tools) is improving rapidly. According to experts, the cybercriminal innovators "invest in proper research, development, quality control and customer service", which include the testing of their new tools against common antivirus products [7]. As a result, these antivirus products are initially unable to detect the new cybercriminal software applications. However, once detected, the cybercriminal innovators rapidly issue updates to their 'customers', prompting "an escalating arms race of online attack and defense" [7,21].

Another possible driver for the growth of financial cybercrime lies in the probability that cyber victims do not always bear the full cost of their system's failures. For instance, in banking, countries with lax banking regulations can pass such costs to their customers and retailers. This could disincentivize these banks from installing robust security systems. Furthermore, banks and financial systems might be inclined to under-report financial cybercrime perpetrated against them (as some of our interviewees have suggested) for fear of revealing their weaknesses and a consequent loss of confidence amongst their clients. Small businesses may be particularly vulnerable to cybercrime. This is mainly because these businesses may not have full knowledge of their IT system and how it functions. Such a lack of knowledge may result from resource constraints that impede the hiring of either qualified technical security personnel or continual refreshing of their security systems. According to a recent report, 40% of cyber crime against small businesses goes unreported [13].

It has also been suggested that IT security companies could be over-reporting the number of certain types of incidents in the hope of marketing products aimed at certain categories of vulnerabilities. Whatever may be the real situation, over- or under-reporting, financial cybercrime has direct economic implications in an increasingly networked business ecosystem, where devices and systems are acquiring more and more processors and communications.

Against these factors, and particularly the profuse use of the Internet, inter alia, cybercrime is increasingly globalising [36,61]. Published evidence

These include multiple sources, such as reports published regularly by security firms (e.g. Symantec, Sophos, MacAfee, Kaspersky, etc.) and other independent international initiatives that offer regular updates, trends and general information on specific types of cybercrime techniques, such as the Anti-Phishing Working Group, focused on activities that direct people to fraudulent websites through phishing, pharming and spoofing; or the Spamhaus Group, which tracks and publishes information about Internet spammers as well as about spam gangs and services.

and the interviews conducted for this research have emphasised that cybercrime is a global issue. The growth of the required skills to perpetrate cybercrimes and the spread of broadband infrastructures, coupled with uneven prosecution procedures and legislations, are driving the fast global redistribution of the geographical locations of cybercrime.

Most cybercrime attacks are currently directed at the US and the UK, since they account for a high proportion of the global financial traffic. Table1 shows that the origin of phishing activities is also concentrated in a few international locations, namely the US, Southern Asia and Eastern Europe. Other locations such as Brazil and India, although lagging behind, also appear to be entering the global cybercrime scene.

Each has developed technological capabilities according to their available skills, domestic context and local vulnerabilities. A snapshot of the key cybercriminal "players" is summarised as follows

Compilation of features provided in various security reports (MacAfee, 2008 [37]; Sophos, 2007 [51], 2008 [52]; Symantec, 2008 [54], 2010 [61]).

:

The United States is reputed to be the major generator of malware and source of cybercriminal attacks. In 2010 over nearly half of the global underground servers were hosted in the US.

Information obtained from Arbor Networks on the basis of and confirmed by Symantec reports (2008 [54], 2009 [66], 2010 [61]). . However, Symantec reports do not provide a total number of underground economy servers on which the study is based upon.

In 2008 the United States was reported as the top country of origin for Web-based attacks, accounting for 38% of the worldwide total. However, the US is also the main target of attacks. In 2009 the United States was the top country for credit card fraud, accounting for 67% of the total reported incidents [61].

Much attention is also placed on China due to its high number of active Internet users and suspicions of State involvement.

There has been much speculation as to whether there was Chinese State involvement (denied by Chinese officials) in the May 2011 cyber-attacks on Google that resulted in hundreds of login passwords being accessed. Arthur, C. Google phishing: Chinese Gmail attack raises cyberwar tensions, The Guardian, 1st June 2011.

In 2010, China had about 450million Internet subscribers compared to 239million in the US.

According to statistics from the China Internet Network Information Center (Internet Statistics available at ) and ITU statistics (available at ).

 Cybercriminals are feeding on this massive penetration and the intensive online habits of Chinese consumers. At least four factors conspire to spur the growing sophistication of the cybercrime industry in China: (1) widespread use of online leisure (including social networking websites, online gaming sites, forums, blogs, and online shopping sites),

.

 (2) low average income of Internet users (94.9% of the Internet users in China have an average monthly income of less than £470 in 2010); (3) high availability of skills due to emphasis on computing€related subjects such as Maths and the Sciences [59]; and (4) most Internet users in 2010 were students (30%), while the unemployed, retired and self-employed segments comprised nearly one quarter of the users.

According to the China Internet Network Information Center (CNNIC), Statistical Report on Internet Development in China, July, 2010, Beijing.

 These factors have plausibly driven the dramatic increase in the population of hackers in China, which is reported to be near four million spanning across just 19 online hacker forums [59]. Most Chinese hackers, however, have been depicted as hackers with "basic training who can tweak and use tools" rather than are capable of producing "genuine" tools [30]. Nonetheless, the ability to use or adapt existing tools does not preclude the perpetration of cybercriminal activities, and there is little to suggest that these basic skills will not evolve into more advanced capabilities for developing innovative criminal applications, such as those for which Russian cybercriminals are renowned (see below).

Russia has traditionally been considered the original home of cybercrime, where high technical skills are combined with a stumbling economy and a long tradition of organised crime.

In 1993, after the European Council invited Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania to apply for EU accession, the Baltic States implemented an intensive period of national and cultural reconstruction following years of encroachment from Russia, especially the penetration of Russian organised crime groups. At the centre of this purge was an attempt to stem the incursion of non-indigenous criminal influence on public-sector employers. It would seem that very early on in the evolution of the Internet, Russian organised crime became aware of its potential. After the collapse of the Soviet Union, the nascent Russian Business Network (RBN) is thought to have taken a keen interest in the IT skills that existed in the Baltic States. It also took a similar interest in the underemployed IT experts in the former Soviet Union's military, many of whom remained unpaid for months on end.

Russian programmers are believed to be behind the most widely used malware-making toolkits such as Mpack and WebAttacker. Dubbed "the mother of cybercrime" the Russian Business Network (RBN) has been linked by security firms to child pornography, corporate blackmail, spam attacks and online identity theft, although most Russian cybercrime is directed at financial fraud, particularly through botnets (collections of compromised computers) and phishing.

R. Blakely, J. Richards, T. Halpin, Cybergang raises fear of new crime wave in Moscow, Timesonline.com, 10 November 2007, , last accessed 8th August 2011.

Although its activities online have often been highly visible, relatively little is known about who is (or was) behind the RBN [54], apart from the fact that it was based in St. Petersburg and could have relocated (or shut down). What is known, however, is that it has no legal identity; it is not registered as a company; and its senior figures are anonymous, known only by their nicknames. Its websites are registered at anonymous addresses with dummy e-mails and it does not advertise for customers. Those who want to use its services may contact it via Internet messaging services and pay with anonymous electronic cash. "RBN is a for-hire service catering to large-scale criminal operations," says VeriSign (the Internet and communication security company). It hosts cybercriminals, ranging from spammers to phishers, bot-herders and "all manner of other fraudsters and wrongdoers from the venal to the vicious" according to VeriSign. The company estimates that a single scam, called Rock Phish (where gullible Internet users were tricked into entering personal financial information such as bank account details) made USD150m in a year (, 20 August 2007). A recent report indicated that in March 2011 Russia was the most frequent source of spam given that a large number of bots are located in its geography.

Messagelabs (2011, March). MessageLabs Intelligence Report March 2011, Symantec Corporation, Cupertino, 2011.

Russian spammers' revenues in 2009, however, have been estimated to be about USD 135billion, with most of them offering counterfeit medical drugs [50].

More recently, Brazil has emerged as a significant player on the global cybercrime stage [20,22]. A main driver that encourages young Brazilians to develop their skills is the lack of any form of effective legislative framework to combat cybercrime. Another factor contributing to the perceived growth of cybercrime in this country is the propensity and readiness of Brazilians to share data via chatrooms, which are a target of cybercriminals to garner personal data for online banking fraud [23,49]. Furthermore, Brazilian hackers are becoming increasingly sophisticated and malware creators are rapidly developing and adapting malware to avoid the security prevention techniques from banks.

Operation Pegasus, launched by Brazilian authorities, arrested 85 people in 2005 as part of a ring planting key loggers (software that logs people's keyboard activity) that helped the alleged criminals steal approximately US$33 million from bank accounts [28].

The number of cyber attacks has escalated, according to the country's Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT), from 68 thousand in 2005 to nearly 360 thousand in 2009. The majority of the cyber attacks are fraud-related (70%), and are largely originated locally (nearly half originated in Brazil).

See CERT.br, Brazilian National Computer Emergency Response Team, Statistics available at .

Although cybercriminal activity remains relatively low in India compared to other emerging economies, despite its well-acknowledged IT capabilities, there has been a notable growth in cybercrime in recent years - reported cases of spam, hacking and fraud have multiplied 50-fold from 2004 to 2007.

CERT-In (Indian Computer Emergency Response Team): Annual Report 2007. Ministry of Communications & Information Technologies, New Delhi, India.

Recent reports indicate that India is the single-most popular source of spam, accounting for nearly 10% of the total volume of spam worldwide in December 2010.

Kaspersky, Lab Spam Report, Kaspersky Lab Inc, December 2010.

 The country has moved from the 11th position to the 5th from 2008 to 2009 in terms of overall cybercriminal activity [61,66]. Additionally, it has been argued that the growth of call centres in India has generated a niche for cybercriminal activity in harvesting data [4,26,43].

The above brief overview of the dispersed locations from which financial cybercrime emanates is indicative of the global nature of this activity and mimics the globalisation process that has been experienced by many legal sectors of the economy [34]. The following section turns to the conceptual elements of the criminal ecosystem and further suggests the aptness of adopting an ecosystem perspective to study cybercrime.

4 Conceptual foundations of the digital business (and cybercrime) ecosystem4.1 Value chains

The literature on value chain analysis defines it as the full range of activities required to bring a product or service from conception, through the different phases of production to the end users or consumers [68]. The concept of value chains also relates to the inputs from multiple actors in various industries, although the relationships illustrated by the value chain tend to be more vertical within one type of industrial commodity than the concept of business ecosystem, which cuts horizontally across many sectors, commodities and services. Nevertheless, the concept of value chains offers important contributions to understanding the ecosystem since: first, it locates particular actors within the value chain and shows how they change position over time. Second, it maps the common flow of activities required for the production of goods and services. Third, it identifies the linkages between the various activities in the chain. Fourth, it helps us to see who gains along the supply chain and identifies the strong and weak links. In other words, it identifies who plays an important role in its success, or how it is governed. Finally, it highlights the importance of upgrading or improvement of capabilities and infrastructure, services and products. A value chain framework thus provides insights into the dynamics of a business ecosystem.

A more in-depth exploration of the cybercrime value chain can be found in Rush and Kraemer-Mbula (2012) "The Cybercrime value chain", International Journal of Cyberspace Sciences and Emergency Management (2012, pending).

As in the legitimate business world, cybercriminals compete and coordinate their actions in order to gain competitive advantage over a specific segment of the market. The sequence of activities, described above, that is required to make a product or service, involves the combination of inputs from various actors, which, in most industries are increasingly distributed globally. A central concern of value chain analysis is to enhance the understanding of, and unpack the relationships between the actors involved in the range of activities that lead to producing a good or service.

Each of the activities from various actors is intended to support the undetected generation of financial profit. Therefore, each activity can be associated with multiple methods of achieving a financial gain within their own niche markets, sources of competitive advantage and gains or value added benefits, combining with each other to form a value chain. Cybercrime can thus be seen as a whole value chain facilitating fraud, with different operations, profit margins, technological capabilities and upgrading of products and services and, consequently, opportunities attached to each stage.

R. Kaplinsky and M. Morris [89], A Handbook for Value Chain Research, International Development Research Centre, Ottawa, 2001.

Within cybercrime value chains resulting in identity theft and credit card fraud, we can identify three basic activities: (1) detection of vulnerabilities in the digital network, including the Internet, (2) distribution and infection of the network, and (3) exploitation of the network vulnerabilities. Fig.1 illustrates the value chain of cybercrime.

As we move down along the chain, from the domain of hackers to the domain of criminal gangs, it is presumed that lower capabilities are involved, lower profit margins as well as more complex organisational structures. The concept of value chains provides an important framework for understanding the phenomenon of cybercrime and how the industry operates.

4.2 Capabilities4.2.1 Capabilities for data harvesting4.2.1.1 Use of non-cyber skills to harvest data

Rummaging in trashcans

Although increasingly more people use shredders, the practice is still limited in households.

and mail interception are tried and tested ways of obtaining personal and financial data. A quicker, more effective and increasingly common method involves working with 'subcontractors' or thieves. 'Insider agents', employees of companies, such as in financial institutions, call centres and bars and restaurants are the prime targets. Credit card fraudsters and identity thieves directly approach potential accomplices who have two distinct characteristics: (1) those who have easy access to customers' personal or financial details; (2) those in poorly paid jobs with access to financial data, so the financial incentive is so attractive that it outweighs concerns about collusion with the fraudster [1].

Confirmed by interviews conducted by [46].

 In an economic environment in which job stability is elusive, loyalty to the employer is threatened.

A recent survey indicates that 60% of global fraud (in which the perpetrator is known) is enabled by insiders. Moreover, this type of fraud experienced an increase of 55% in one year between 2010 and 2011 (Global Fraud Survey 2011/12; KROLL, (2011), quoted in the National Fraud Authority [41] Annual Fraud Indicator Report.

 Hence there is always the temptation of quick financial rewards.

4.2.1.2 Use of cyber capabilities to harvest data

Credit card fraudsters are becoming much more adept at exploiting new technologies for their criminal activities. They are keeping pace with technological developments and even outpacing them through the adaptation and upgrading of existing software tools. At the higher end of the generation of crimeware tools and distribution (harvesting fraudsters), increasing specialisation in the methods for data harvesting poses greater challenges for the prevention of cybercrime. Specialisation allows cybercriminals to be ahead of the protection techniques, and new tactics arise constantly for each type of threat [46]. Spamming, phishing and cracking are the three main techniques for data harvesting. We explain each below.

Spamming is the practice of sending unwanted e-mail messages, frequently with commercial content, in large quantities to an indiscriminate set of recipients. Increasingly, e-mail spam today is sent via 'zombies', that is, networks of virus- or worm-infected personal computers worldwide. It was estimated that more than 90% of all e-mail was spam in 2009.

Information about spamming is collected by Spamhaus. See .

Recently it has been calculated that the worldwide spam cost to business alone is USD130 billion annually [75]. Despite the banning of sending unsolicited bulk email by all Internet service providers, the number of spammers has exponentially grown and new trends include the growing use of social networking sites (i.e. Facebook and Myspace) as spamming platforms.

The skills deployed in spamming vary in their sophistication. An example of a low skill in spamming involves sending bulk unsolicited e-mails requesting personal details, such as the notorious 'Nigerian Letter' scam (also called the '419 fraud').

This is also referred to as the 'Advance Fee Fraud', named '419 Fraud' after the relevant section of the Nigerian Criminal Code.

This involves e-mails in which the target is enticed to advance sums of money in the hope of realising a significantly larger gain, through high returns from the unsuspecting victim's 'investment'. The skills for spamming, however, are becoming more technically sophisticated. For instance, nine out of ten spam messages now contain little more than a few simple words and a web link, which, when clicked, downloads malicious code to steal data, according to a survey of major computer company's security division. 'Spamvertised sites' also are found in many spam e-mails which contain links to a website or websites, which offer products, ranging from adult entertainment to financial services to health products, thereby presenting themselves as legitimate marketing sites.

Phishing, now popularly labelled as a social engineering technique,

Social engineering is the practice of obtaining confidential information by manipulation of legitimate users. Phishing is social engineering because it tricks people to divulge information, perform certain actions or break security procedures. Trend Micro, Threat Roundup and Forecast, London (2008). See also [58]. Social engineering is also explored in a Whitepaper issued by ENISA (2008) "Social Engineering: Exploring the Weakest Link", The European Network and Information Security Agency.

is a sophisticated form of spam. Phishing is the fraudulent process of attempting to acquire sensitive information, such as usernames, passwords and credit card details, by masquerading as a trustworthy entity in an electronic communication. The practice is often conducted by sending e-mails that look as if they come from a financial institution. This information is later exploited for a financial gain (either using the information directly to obtain goods or services by deception or selling the information to another criminal). Some phishing techniques require high levels of technical skill and know-how. For instance, cybercriminals are leveraging new technologies to invent new forms of phishing, for example, 'spear phishing'. This is any highly targeted phishing attack in which a fake e-mail from a seemingly internal person to an organisation is sent to all the employees or certain members.

Microsoft, . Another form of phishing is 'whale' phishing, in which high profile individuals are singles out for phishing attaches.

 Also, cloning the websites of retailers is one quick way to obtain financial and personal data. These cloned websites closely resemble the real ones and require close scrutiny to spot the difference. The Anti-Phishing Working Group [12] reported that more than 300 brands were hijacked by phishers in a six-month period during 2011 [12]. In an attempt to deal with this problem, Google, Facebook, Microsoft, Yahoo and 11 other big tech companies are jointly designing a system for combating phishing email scams. However, there are also examples of 'phishing kits' available for cybercriminals with low technical skills. Phishing (technical) kits typically bundle all the content required to replicate a targeted website and these are offered freely on the Internet.

Crackers are specialists in gaining unauthorised access to other computers. This is generally achieved through the application of particular tools, programming skills and computer knowledge. This activity has gradually moved away from the original virus writing, motivated by the reputation to become a key component of the cybercrime industry. Crackers can also develop malware (software viruses/programmes) with a financial motive in mind, and are currently the top cause of reported data breaches.

Information on data breaches is regularly collected by the Identity Resource Center; see .

Eight hundred data breaches were reported worldwide in 2008, which resulted in more than 200million identities exposed. This figure has decreased to 550 in 2010,

Global data breaches of information are collected by DataLossDB. See .

 although the persistence of the problem affects all sectors, public and private, while the proliferation of larger centralised databases in the private and public sectors threatens more personal data being lost or abused.

Crackers are generally at the 'highly-skilled' end of the cybercrime value chain. However, different types of capabilities are required to either adapt legitimate software tools for criminal purposes or develop malicious software for specific criminal use. The operation of crackers has also changed, and rather than working in isolation they currently often share their ideas in user communities. Many such communities are characterised by an open sharing of ideas and innovations, termed 'free revealing' [76]. Moreover, new evidence suggests that crackers and malware writers are gradually entering the hierarchical structure of cybercrime organisations, where they have their own well-defined role and reward system [14,31,59]. Given the high technical nature of their skills, it is expected that crackers represent a small percentage of the cybercriminal population. However, the way they operate, their role in the governance of the cybercriminal value chain and the evolution of the trends, skills and linkage with traditional criminal gangs, are still largely unknown.

4.2.2 Capabilities in the exploitation of information

At the lower end, specialisation in exploitation is minimising the level of IT related skills required to perpetrate crime. Some examples are:

a) Use of non-cyber skills to exploit information

Many credit card fraudsters prefer to obtain cards themselves but without stealing them. One way of doing this is known as "account takeover."

[1], p.9.

 Here, the fraudster manages to obtain sufficient information about the victim, such as from billing statements, pre-approved credit card offers and receipts, to impersonate him or her in bank dealings, in person, by telephone or in writing. The fraudster changes the address associated with the account so that all mail is delivered to another address. The fraudster then gets a new card by reporting the loss of an existing card or requests an additional card. Upon receipt of the card and the pin, the fraudster uses the card. The transactions are not immediately detected, because the statement is sent to another address and the victim is unaware of the loss of the card. Only when the transactions become too obvious or high in value will the rightful owner realise that the card has been used fraudulently.

In the UK, according to CIFAS [15], the first 9months of 2009 saw a 23% increase when compared with the same period in 2008. While some observers may regard this as rather worrying, this increase was on top of a staggering 207% increase in the previous year. Cases of account takeover have risen by 238% in total when comparing the first nine months of 2009 with the same period in 2007. In terms of the individual victim, these figures work out to a 36% increase in the number of victims of impersonation during the first nine months of 2009 when compared with the same period in 2008.

b) Use of cyber skills to exploit the information

The trend towards the development and marketing of user-friendly tools for criminal exploitation is rapidly developing into crimeware-as-a-service (CaaS). The emergence of crimeware as a service releases criminals from having to deal with the technical challenges of cybercrimes. Some of these services include crimeware toolkits. As noted above, these provide readymade tools for criminals to gather and sort out the data stolen, minimising the necessary coding skills to operate them [19]. The director of security strategies from a large IT multinational said "for subscriptions starting as low as USD20 per month, such enterprises sell fully managed exploit engines that spyware distributors and spammers can use to infiltrate systems worldwide".

Gunter Ollman quoted at: .

 It is likely that CaaS will increasingly hamper the ability of law enforcement to track malicious hackers.

One commentator has argued that the virtual relationships within online communities "... encourage the social deskilling of the individual through the specialisation and compartmentalisation of interactions" [58, p. 33]. However, the examples presented above suggest both increasing acquisition of technical skills and deskilling, depending on the type and activity of the cybercrime. Consequently, capability is being spread across a dramatically increasing range and number of cybercriminals. Highly capable cybercriminals are developing skills that will harvest data worth vast sums of money. However, even a barely capable cybercriminal can still make an effective living with a small investment of funds and limited computer literacy.

Networks of criminals specialise, cooperate and compete with the ultimate goal of generating an illicit profit in this cybercriminal ecosystem. Their interconnection and dependence means that to pursue their individual interests, they need to become part of value chains, where different actors specialise, link and upgrade, driven by innovation. The strategic position of a firms and its' activities in the value chain helps determine how it approaches business and generates a profit. A wide variety of actors participate in the cybercrime ecosystem at various levels, creating different business models. Some of these are explored below.

A firm's capability is "a collection of routines that confers upon an organisation's management the ability to produce significant outputs of a particular type" [69]. Scholars, however, argue that dynamic capabilities, more than just 'routine' capabilities, are required to create and sustain competitive advantage in a changing business environment [70]. Dynamism connotes change, so dynamic capabilities are those that extend, modify or create capabilities [69] to meet the challenges and demands of the marketplace. Such capabilities, therefore, underpin the ability of an organisation to make best use of new equipment or technologies to produce novel and innovative products or services, and hence improve their productivity and competitive advantage [71,72].

Within an ecosystem, the identification of the firm's distinctive competencies, skills and capabilities is necessary in order to assess if specialisation in a product or process also helps to determine the behaviour of the individual firm within the value chain [79]. As with legitimate businesses that have to innovate and develop new skills, specialisation is also driving changes in the skills needed to perpetrate cybercrime at different points in the value chain. While we acknowledge that firms can change without reliance on dynamic capabilities [73], we argue that the cybercriminal 'enterprise' reflects capability-building in the ways that Teece [55] shows how enterprises can maintain competitive advantage through dynamic capabilities. He disaggregates dynamic capabilities into the capacity to sense and shape opportunities and threats, seize opportunities, and maintain competitiveness through enhancing, combining, protecting, and, when necessary, reconfiguring the business enterprise's intangible and tangible assets.

Eisenhardt and Martin ([74], p. 21) also discuss dynamic capabilities in terms of specific and strategic organisational processes, noting that organisations become engaged in "alliancing and strategic decision making that create value for firms in dynamic markets by manipulating resources into new value creating strategies". The financial cybercriminal "market" exhibits such dynamism and the cybercriminal enterprise is rather adept at sensing, shaping and seizing opportunities, manipulating its resources to maintain competitiveness. It primarily does this by adapting and developing capabilities to create and exploit opportunities for innovative forms of credit card fraud and identity theft.

A capability analysis also helps to illuminate the generation and adaptation of the new capabilities, both at the highly-technical level and other types of capabilities (e.g. social engineering, process management, etc.). The analysis of the capabilities involved in cybercriminal activities illuminates the process of specialisation of the perpetrators. Understanding the specialisation process is critical in order to anticipate the strategic behaviour of a firm, as well as to understand their capabilities and their innovation activities. Credit card fraudsters and identity thieves use a combination of traditional and new skills to acquire data and perpetrate fraud. These capabilities generally involve both cyber and non-cyber skills and can be illustrated by focussing on two essential credit card fraud and identity theft activities, such as data harvesting and exploitation (more below).

4.3 Business models4.3.1 Offline business models

Although the Internet is a common meeting and workplace for cybercriminals, we have already seen that some credit card fraud and ID theft still takes place in a traditional offline fashion. These activities are usually at higher risk, since they lack the anonymity of the Internet. However, offline activities have provided an opportunity for traditional crime gangs to exploit the economic opportunities of cybercrime businesses, which have benefited from their existing structure, hierarchy and occasional funding from other illicit activities. Two likely offline business models are the loyalty business model and business process outsourcing.

a) The loyalty business model is used when company resources are employed to increase the loyalty of customers and other stakeholders to meet corporate expectations. Whilst supermarkets use loyalty cards, organised crime groups may maintain the loyalty of gang members and the code of silence with cash "incentives" [17] or the threat of violence or extortion.

b) The business process outsourcing model (BPO) involves contracting operations and responsibilities of specific business functions (or processes) to a third-party service provider. It is traditionally associated with large manufacturing firms outsourcing large segments of their supply chain. Today, it is primarily used to refer to outsourcing of services. In the cybercrime business, given the variety of technical and organisational skills required to perpetrate certain crimes, many of the services will likely be hired or outsourced. It is well reported [37] that criminal organisations are increasingly hiring (legitimate) financial specialists to conduct their money laundering transactions in countries where financial jurisdictions are 'safer'. Similarly, criminal gangs can also hire the technical expertise they need to perpetrate one type of attack, ensuring, through a mixture of rewards and threats, that the technical expert will conduct the assignment effectively. Here we note the "connection" between the legal and dark networks of Raab and Milward, and the "interconnectedness" of Moore, Iansiti and Levien, and other scholars who have written on business ecosystems.

4.3.2 Hybrid business models

A hybrid business model results from the combination of physical (off-line) and web channels (online). Many authors have differentiated hybrid models from Internet-only businesses models, using terms like 'bricks and clicks', also known as "clicks and mortar", "surf and turf," "cyber-enhanced retailing," and "hybrid e-commerce" [3,42,53,56] and swarming business models.

a) The bricks and clicks business model and its variations generally describe the partnership between Internet businesses and traditional distribution companies, for instance the successful business model adopted by Amazon, where orders placed online are physically distributed by the postal system. In the cybercrime business, the integration of e-commerce with physical channels takes place mostly during the final transformation of stolen information into cash, without which the entire process would have no value. The business model of drop services provides an example of a combination of web channels of communication with the purchaser of illicit goods online, and off-line provision of a physical address to mail the stolen goods.

b) The swarming business model involves the temporary collaboration of individuals to meet a particular challenge or goal. In the legitimate world, members of the "swarm" work towards a collective interest, which is broadly defined by any of the stakeholders and is driven by innovation [24,25]. Many legitimate businesses have used collaborative innovation networks to facilitate close cooperation between customers and product developers [24]. Given the range of skills required in the various forms of financial cybercrime, it is plausible that swarms can be born online, similar to what we call the "Internet community business model", but in most cases they combine physical and online means for communication (online collaboration among individuals who also meet in person). One distinct feature of the model is that swarms generate for a specific purpose and for a limited period of time, until the goal is achieved (unlike the Internet-based model). In cybercrime, swarms could be generated for the purpose of cracking.

4.3.3 Internet-based business models

The growth of Internet-based businesses in the legitimate world has resulted in many classifications and methods of conducting business over the Internet. E-commerce has given rise to new kinds of business models. The benefits for customers and suppliers offered by online businesses and Internet technology over physical channels have been highlighted by many commentators (e.g. [10,48,35]) and include reduced operational and overhead costs, scale and scope, access to wider markets, lower inventory and building costs, flexibility in sourcing inputs, improved transaction automation and the ability to bypass intermediaries. Cybercriminals benefit from all these advantages as well as enjoy anonymity. The Internet provides criminals with a favourable environment to disguise their identity, even amongst trusted colleagues, making them hard for law enforcement agencies to locate.

Some models identified in our research include:

a) Advertising-based models: This model is used legally by companies that provide content or services to visitors and sell advertising to businesses that want to reach those visitors. The advertising based model is widely used by Internet Relay Chats (IRC) and web forum operators. In the underground economy, advertised items include bundles of credit card numbers, identity theft information, online banking information and skilled labour for hire. Discounts are often offered for bulk purchases [54].

b) Brokerage model: At the heart of the brokerage model are third parties known as brokers, who bring sellers and buyers of products and services together to engage in transactions. The broker usually charges a fee to at least one party involved in a transaction, sometimes both, in much the same way a real estate agent charges a fee for a successful sale. In the underground cybercriminal business, this would be illustrated by the providers of referral services. These specialised services act as a 'trusted' intermediary between a seller and buyer of malware and other illegal services. Such agents hold the money on the transaction until a buyer has had a chance to check that the goods or services purchased function as promised. Their fees can range from 2% to 4% of the total transaction [54].

c) Internet community model: This business model is based on the creation of a virtual community of interested users who support the development of products through voluntary donations. A legitimate example is the 'Open Source' community. There is evidence that communities of hackers are developing attacking tools mimicking Open Source communities [27].

There are examples such as the distribution of Try2DDoS, a tool that automates distributed denial of service attacks. It was first released in June 2005 on Underground Konnekt, a French hacker website. Over the next two years, identical source code turned up in China, Guatemala, Russia and Argentina. As the programme moved around the globe within the online community of hackers, the tool gained new capabilities, including support for Spanish and Chinese languages. Dan Goodin, (2008)[27], Online crime gangs embrace open source ethos: Malware gets globalized, 17th January 2008; .

 This community of 'users' plays a critical role in fostering innovation in this business model. There is also the opportunity for revenue to be generated around open source from related services such as systems integration, product support, tutorials and user documentation.

d) Crimeware-as-a-Service (CaaS): Parallel to the concept of software-as-a-service [57],

Software as a service (SaaS) is a model of software delivery where an application is hosted as a service provided to customers across the Internet. This model is centred on separating software possession and ownership from its use. Turner, M., Budgen, D., and Brereton, P. (2003)[57]. Turning software into a service. Computer, 36(10), pp 38-44 (October).

 crimeware-as-a-service is rapidly gaining attention in the underground economy. Using CaaS, criminals can now rent malware and hosting services along with any patches needed to defeat security software. The final user only needs to have a target and to identify the type of data they seek to steal, while the technical work can be hired. The emergence of CaaS releases criminals from having to deal with the technical challenges of cybercrime. Under this business model, everything can be rented, from crimeware toolkits to pay-per-infection services.

e) Crimeware toolkits offer off-the-shelf tools that allow criminals to gather and sort out the data stolen, minimising the need for coding skills to operate them [19]. One director of security strategies for a major corporation said, "for subscriptions starting as low as $20 (£13.40) per month, such enterprises sell fully managed exploit engines that spyware distributors and spammers can use to infiltrate systems worldwide".

Gunter Ollmann, at IBM's Internet Security Systems X-Force team quoted at: Vijayan, J. (2007) Hackers now offer subscription services, support for their malware, Computer World.com. Available at: .

f) The pay-per-infection model emulates the 'pay-as-you-go' approach, based on actual usage rates. These businesses sell other criminals code that enables them to infect websites with malware or spyware. One interviewee found a website that was initially charging (EURO)40 (£35) each time the spyware was downloaded to personal machines; however, the site offered more favourable rates when the traffic increased.

Warner, T. (2007), eCriminal eCommerce and the Web Models and Techniques Used to Support it, Finjan, Basingstoke, UK.

The discussion above shows that business models are not independent from each other; instead there are often combinations of the different models. For instance, the swarming model, where participants work together on a common goal, can also include crime-as-a service elements. Many sources, as discussed above, have made assumptions about the various types of business model and their features but empirical evidence of each model is still lacking. This is hardly surprising given the murky nature of cybercrime. Still, with the relentless adoption of the Internet for conducting online business, international cooperation in promoting cybersecurity and the concomitant acquisition of technical expertise by law enforcement authorities to improve cybersecurity and combat cybercrime, continues as an urgent policy objective nationally and internationally.

The integration of business models into the criminal ecosystem allows opportunities for the identification of the typical cybercriminal business structures. Yet all business models have weaknesses as well as strengths [78]. It is thus arguable that, by acquiring a better understanding of the weaknesses of the cybercrime business models (how they are organised and operate), better perspectives and measures for dealing with cybercrime may be developed. Similarly, a better understanding of the cybercriminal business models is likely to facilitate a greater degree of understanding of the criminal activity, which in turn could provide more grounded intelligence that could be used to neutralise such activities.

The third contributing body of work that is important in understanding how the cybercrime ecosystem works is that of business models. The term 'business model' is used in the literature to describe the key components of a business, and has gained particular interest in research related to e-businesses [3,5,9,47]. A business model is a conceptual tool that articulates the vision of a business and conveys a high-level understanding of the overall strategic goals of a business and its interaction with rivals [77,29,38].

In any given industry, the methods of doing business may vary between actors and over time in response to changing market conditions, technological innovations, new product strategies, competition, among others. While little is known about the types of business models that operate in the underworld, we do know that all cybercriminals want to make money. We also know that every business model has its own inherent strengths and weaknesses.

While some models are quite simple, others can be more intricately woven. Rush et al. [46] identified three predominant business models: off-line business models, Internet-based business models and hybrid models (a combination of the previous two). Since most cybercrime activities take place online, there are more Internet-based examples of business models. However, it is still worth noting that a significant component of cybercrime activities takes place offline, as well as a combination of online and offline methods. Below we present a number of plausible business models, but further examination is much needed.

We have already discussed that a business ecosystem relies on "the performance of individual firms and the utility of individual products depends much on the performance of other firms and products in the ecosystem.....[and] an ecosystem is a network of organisations that drive and create/deliver services or products" ([67]: 5). As Moore [40] had intimated, business ecosystems evolve and are dynamic, and like natural or biological systems, they behave like an "organism" which responds to its environment and continually evolves. For instance, consumer tastes change over time and, therefore, the constituents of the business ecosystem that supplies this particular consumer demand have to react accordingly in order to succeed in the market. This biological analogy emphasises the interdependence of all actors in the business environment who "co-evolve their capabilities and roles". Thus, innovation is central to the creation, development and life of a business ecosystem and is, as Moore has also suggested, a "catalysing element for the evolution of the ecosystem".

Cybercriminals are increasingly operating in a business ecosystem in much the same way that companies, such as Microsoft, IBM, Cisco and Hewlett Packard, have successfully used their environment to define and establish their alliances and networks to sell their products and services. In particular, the traditional, ethnocentric organisational structures of criminal organisations have increasingly eroded to allow new sets of actors to collaborate. As with companies, the cybercriminal ecosystem has acquired new partners, knowledge, ideas and skills to fuel innovation and thereby has expanded the range of its cybercrime activities.

In a business ecosystem, the collective health of other actors who influence the creation and delivery of the product or service is fundamental to a company's success [62]. Firms "operate in a business environment of shared fates and business models, and see their ecosystems as helping them become more resilient to market changes... to achieve market success and sustain performance" [32]. Similar to legitimate businesses, the success of certain cyber-criminal activities may be dependent on innovations generated in other segments of the industry [18]. For instance, for cybercriminals to become more effective in perpetrating credit card fraud, they need to have access to, or develop more, sophisticated malicious software that allows them to infect more computer networks and get hold of the credit card data they want. In most cases, the criminal that steals the data is unlikely to have the ability to undertake innovations in developing new malicious software; therefore, their activities depend on the innovations from other actors in the industry. Moreover, most actors in the cybercrime industry must remain adept at overcoming the preventative obstacles and the risk of identification and detection. In sum, business ecosystems emphasise the interconnectedness between the relationships, capabilities and business models among players in the network fuelled by innovation.

As described by Raab and Milward [44, p 3], a cybercrime ecosystem is, in effect, a "dark network" in which there may be "interpenetration between illegal and legal networks". They further explain that there is a connection between legal networks, such as those aimed to destroy these dark networks. Such 'interpenetration' between these legal and illegal networks can be illustrated by a law enforcement officer or informant posing as a member of a dark network.

An example can be seen in an FBI sting operation, in which the agency used an informant to target a top crime site, Shadowcrew.com, which was eventually shut down.

So while networks are often perceived positively, for instance, they are formed to solve a political, social and economic problem, dark networks,

 Raab and Millward argue, need to be studied so that policymakers may "reformulate the problem of illegal activity in network terms" in order to tackle these problems. The authors specifically suggest that policymakers, and scholars interested in the study of networks, need to learn (1) more about the activities of these networks; (2) how they operate; and (3) how they are organised. The following sections will elaborate on these three aspects.

To explore the core elements of the cybercrime ecosystem, we refer to the key writings on value chains, dynamic capabilities and business models to help reveal what the cybercriminal activities are and how cybercrime operates and functions. The following sections address each body of literature, highlighting mainly its key relevance and utility to understanding the cybercrime ecosystem.

5 Conclusions

The organisational and technological capabilities of cybercriminals will likely advance and grow in the foreseeable future. As the use of cyberspace develops further, new opportunities will open up, for instance in the observed rapid growth in mobile web usage and social media. It remains to be seen how the current global financial crisis will affect this situation. We have already seen how powerful emerging economies (the so-called BRICs, for example) are already playing significant roles within the cybercrime ecosystem. If the crisis deepens and persists, this may encourage a new generation of under- or unemployed youth with IT skills to seek entry into the profitable and comparatively low risk world of cybercrime. We have also discussed the range of countries that have become "IT-savvy," from where many cybercriminals are conducting their illicit activities. It is arguable that as IT capabilities are further developed in countries such as Africa, other parts of Europe, South-East Asia and Latin America, and exacerbated by a prolonged financial exigency, the growth prospects of this criminal activity are likely to increase.

Against this global spread of cybercrime, we have aimed to show why the concept of business ecosystems provides a useful approach to exploring the complex global environment in which cybercriminals operate. In the absence of coordinated global governance and leadership, criminal networks are likely to proliferate or consolidate in order to pursue convergent goals and interests. From an analytical viewpoint, digital business ecosystems provide a holistic framework to analyse the cybercrime 'industry' from a variety of angles, including its horizontal connections to other legitimate sectors (e.g. software production, Internet services providers, etc.). By adopting the ecosystem analogy, we have shown that the cybercrime ecosystem is continually evolving as it develops new criminal techniques, as well as responds to the external environment in which online activity and transactions continue unabated. The recent hacking of the Sony Playstation website in which millions of personal data were stolen is a distressing reminder that cybercriminals (and hackers with 'political' agendas) are unrelenting in their activities [11]. We believe that the ecosystem perspective, once fully populated with reliable data, will permit a clearer view of the multiple actors within the cybercrime universe.

This paper has also attempted to examine cybercrime through an innovation lens, by examining how cybercriminals innovate, what the sources of innovation are and from where they emanate. We argue that by doing so, we have also contributed to the broad literature on cybercriminal activity, which is mainly populated by scholars in the fields of criminology, psychology, sociology, law and information technology. Important and necessary as these fields are for understanding the roots of cybercrime, the law for tackling it and the security measures that may be deployed to combat this felonious activity, an innovation perspective for studying this activity provides an added dimension to its activities, operation and organisation, which taken together, expands the understanding of this activity. Furthermore, the greater the awareness of the new ways that cybercriminals use to compile, package, distribute and market their products and services, the greater the success of dealing with counter measures against cybercrime. As concerns regarding the systematic collection of cybercriminal activities continue to worry national enforcement authorities, we believe that the framework presented in this paper could further help to identify the kinds of data required for capturing the actors and activities of cybercrime. In the UK for instance, the UK National Fraud Authority (NFA) set up the National Fraud Reporting Centre in 2011 (Action Fraud)

.

to improve the low reporting activity of fraud victims, as well financial and cyber-enabled fraud.

An enhanced understanding of cybercriminal activities could have a number of policy and practical implications for the communities charged with tackling cybercrime. Knowledge of how cybercriminals innovate, operate and organise their activities could plausibly aid law enforcement officers and policymakers to devise more effective strategies to deal with them. For instance, Kaplinsky [33, p 126] argues that an advantage of value chain analysis shifts "the focus from 'point' to 'systemic' efficiency," which could imply that it would be more efficient for policymakers and the law enforcement community to understand the cybercriminal value chain than to deal with each kind of cybercrime discretely. Similarly, a deepened understanding of the dynamic capabilities required and the development of new business models within the cybercrime ecosystem, could help in the identification of significant trends (often mimicking legitimate sectors of the economy). Such insights and knowledge about the activities of networks could help criminal enforcement authorities and policy makers to concentrate what are often limited resources in order to increase the effectiveness of their response.

Developing proactive measures to address complex, uncertain and globally interconnected issues, calls for the use of tools and approaches to analyse trends and directions of change, but importantly with a long-term perspective. Scenario planning and foresight are growing areas of interest that support strategic thinking by developing a range of possible ways in which the future could unfold, anticipating trends and identifying optimal policy responses to address each possible scenario. Foresight analysis has been deployed in cybercrime studies - a notable example is the "Foresight's Cyber Trust and Crime Prevention Project" sponsored by the UK Home Office in 2004.

See .

These exercises provide valuable insights on the perceptions of risks of cybercrime. The integration of an ecosystem perspective to foresight exercises could add value to future analyses.

Addressing cybercrime is becoming a worldwide priority - in 2011 the UK government allocated £30m over a period of four years to develop an e-Crime Unit exclusively dedicated to tackle computer intrusion, denial of service attacks and Internet fraud. Since its establishment there have been notable successes in terms of prosecutions and arrests.

Operation Podium led recently to over 100 arrests related to Internet fraud connected to the Olympics (BBC, 2012); and Operation Dynamaphone, which resulted in £5.5m worth of harm saved. Three individuals were jailed for 13years for their part in a concerted attack on the UK and international banking system. (BBC, 2012).

Yet these measures remain predominantly reactive, that is, taking action after the perpetration of the crime, although the UK Foresight project (see above) signals recognition that anticipation of the (new) types of cybercrime is a requirement for effective measures.

In the U.S. attempts are being made to be more proactive in their strategies against cybercrime. For instance, the Federal Bureau of Investigation led the formation of a National Cyber Investigative Joint Task Force (NCIJTF) and in 2008, the U.S. President mandated the NCIJTF to be responsible for the coordination, integration and the sharing of information related to all domestic cyber threat investigations. This Task Force includes 18 intelligence and law enforcement agencies, working together to identify key players and schemes. Its goal is to predict, anticipate and prevent cybercrime and to identify and pursue the organisations behind cybercriminal activities.

The methodology proposed in this paper can help identify where in the value chain those successes have taken place. Moreover, we argue that the application of an ecosystems framework may help to better understand not only the business models and interactions between criminals, but also the "mirror" approach of techniques and models that have been used by law enforcement agencies in their prosecution activities, in such a way that good practices can be replicated and scarce resources more efficiently allocated.

It becomes apparent that to deal with cybercrime effectively, concerted action by national and international law enforcement, separately and together, and stringent corporate information security measures are indispensable, given the global nature of cybercrime. Thus far, our research has concentrated on devising a conceptual framework, which would aid decision-makers working in law-enforcement and IT security. Of course, an integral part of the ecosystem s also to be found at the level of the organisation/company level and the individual. These far, the conceptual model only covers the criminal aspects of the ecosystem and a next step will be to extend it to encompass their victim's. It has been suggested that much of cybercrime is aided and abetted via insider knowledge or simply lax security. Too many companies think that they are either two small to be a target, that they have taken adequate protection but rarely update their defences, or are simply unaware of the dangers faced. Former Navy Admiral and National Security Agency director Mike McConnell once told a forum on cyber security that "good cyber hygiene" is imperative for eliminating security risks that companies face.

See Taylor Amerding [6], "Thwarted by security by enterprises, cyber criminals target SMBs. See . May 15, 2012.

It is also, of course, the responsibility of individuals to protect the confidentiality of their personal data and to exercise care in giving them out. Developing an awareness of individual information security, however, assumes that cybercrime affects the social behaviour of the individual by making him or her, among other things, more careful about data security. The so-called 'social-engineering' skills and techniques used to part an individual from their data and money are just as dynamic as the technical development of new and evermore powerful malware. Furthering our understanding of the changing nature of such techniques, capabilities and the new business models to which they are attached would be useful for those organisations (governmental and non-governmental), which are attempting to educate the public about cybersecurity.
